Full transcript of the ABC News exclusive interview with President Joe Biden.  120 DAYS TO ELECTION DAY  ABC‚Äôs George Stephanopoulos‚Äô exclusive interview with President Biden  July 5 2024 9:10 PM  One-on-one with President Biden: ABC News Exclusive  ABC‚Äôs George Stephanopoulos  President Joe Biden in his first television interview since his CNN debate with former President Donald Trump sat down with ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos in Madison Wisconsin on Friday.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Mr. President thank you for doing this.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Thank you for having me.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let‚Äôs start with the debate. eh You and your team said have said you had a bad night. But your‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Sure did.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But your friend Nancy Pelosi actually framed the question that I think is on the minds of millions of Americans. Was this a bad episode or the sign of a more serious condition?  <!-- more --> PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: It was a bad episode. No indication of any serious condition. I was exhausted. I didn‚Äôt listen to my instincts in terms of preparing and‚Äì and a bad night.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know you say you were exhausted. And‚Äì and I know you‚Äôve said that before as well but you came‚Äì and you did have a tough month. But you came home from Europe about 11 or 12 days before the debate spent six days in Camp David. Why wasn‚Äôt that enough rest time enough recovery time?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Because I was sick. I was feeling terrible. Matter of fact the docs with me. I asked if they did a COVID test because they‚Äôre trying to figure out what was wrong. They did a test to see whether or not I had some infection you know a virus. I didn‚Äôt. I just had a really bad cold.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And‚Äì did you ever watch the debate afterwards?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt think I did no.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Well what I‚Äôm try‚Äì what I want to get at is what were you experiencing as you were going through the debate? Did you know how badly it was going?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yeah look. The whole way I prepared nobody‚Äôs fault mine. Nobody‚Äôs fault but mine. I uh‚Äì I prepared what I usually would do sittin‚Äô down as I did come back with foreign leaders or National Security Council for explicit detail. And I realized‚Äìbout partway through that you know all‚Äì I get quoted the New York Times had me down at ten points before the debate nine now or whatever the hell it is. The fact of the matter is what I looked at is that he also lied 28 times. I couldn‚Äôt‚Äì I mean the way the debate ran not‚Äì my fault no one else‚Äôs fault no one else‚Äôs fault.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But it seemed like you were having trouble from the first question in even before he spoke.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I just had a bad night. You‚Äôve had some bad interviews once in a while. I‚Äì I can‚Äôt remember any but I‚Äôm sure you did.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äôve had plenty. I guess the question of‚Äì the problem is here for a lot of Americans watching is you‚Äôve said going back to 2020 ‚ÄúWatch me‚Äù to people who are concerned about your age. And you know 50 million Americans watched that debate. It seemed to confirm fears they already had.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well look. After that debate I did ten major events in a row including until 2:00 in the morning after the debate. I did events in North Carolina. I did events in‚Äîin in Georgia did events like this today large crowds overwhelming response no‚Äì no‚Äì no slipping. And so I just had a bad night. I don‚Äôt know why.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And‚Äì how‚Äì how quickly did it‚Äì did it come to you that you were having that bad night?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well it came to me I was havin‚Äô a bad night when I realized that even when I was answering a question even though they turned his mic off he was still shouting. And I‚Äì I let it distract me. I‚Äì I‚Äôm not blaming it on that but I realized that I just wasn‚Äôt in control.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Part of the other concern is that‚Äì this seems to fit into a pattern of decline that has been reported on recently. New York Times had a headline on July 2nd ‚ÄúBiden‚Äôs lapses are said to be increasingly common and worrisome.‚Äù Here‚Äôs what they wrote.  ‚ÄúPeople who‚Äôve spent time with President Biden over the last few months or so said the lapses appear to have grown more frequent more pronounced and after Thursday d‚Äì Thursday‚Äôs debate more worrisome. By many accounts as evidenced by video footage observation and interviews Mr. Biden is not the same today as he was even when he took office three-and-a-half years ago.‚Äù Similar reporting in The Washington Post and the Wall Street Journal. Are you the same man today that you were when you took office three-and-a-half years ago?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: In terms of successes yes. I also was the guy who put together a peace plan for the Middle East that may be comin‚Äô to fruition. I was also the guy that expanded NATO. I was also the guy that grew the economy. All the individual things that were done were ideas I had or I fulfilled. I moved on.  And so for example you know ‚ÄúWe-Well that was true then what‚Äôs Biden done lately?‚Äù Di-you-just just see today just announced 200000 new jobs. We‚Äôre movin‚Äô in the direction that no one‚Äôs ever taken on. I know you know this from days in‚Äì in‚Äì in the‚Äì in the government.  I took on big pharma. I beat them. No one said I could beat them. I took on all the things we said we got done were told we couldn‚Äôt get done. And part of it is what I said when I ran was I wanted to do three things: Restore some decency to the office restore some support for the middle class instead of trickle down economics both from the middle out and the bottom up the way the wealthy still do fine everyone does better and unite the country.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But what has all that work over the last three-and-a-half years cost you physically mentally emotionally?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I‚Äì I‚Äì I just think it cost me a really bad night bad run but you know I‚Äì George. I have‚Äì I‚Äôm optimistic about this country. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre a country of losers that he points out. I don‚Äôt think America‚Äôs in tough shape. I think America is on the cusp of breaking through in so many incredible opportunities.  In this next term I‚Äôm gonna make sure we gotta‚Äì straighten out the tax system. I‚Äôm gonna make sure we‚Äôre in a situation where we have healthcare for all people where we‚Äôre in a position where we have‚Äì have childcare and eldercare free up‚Äì and all these things.  One thing I‚Äôm proudest of is remember when my economic plan was put forward? A lot of the mainstream economists said ‚ÄúThis is not gonna work.‚Äù Guess what? We now have 16 Nobel laureates 16 of ‚Äòem in economics saying that ‚ÄúBiden‚Äôs next term would be a sig‚Äì enor‚Äì based on what he wants to do enormous success.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs plan would cause a recession and sig-nif‚Äì gi‚Äì increase inflation. I‚Äôve made great progress and that‚Äôs what I plan on doin‚Äô. And we can do this.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äì I‚Äì I understand that and I‚Äôm not disputing that. What I‚Äôm asking you is‚Äì about your personal situation. Do you dispute that there have been more lapses especially in the last several months?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Can I run the 100 in 10 flat? No. But I‚Äôm still in good shape.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Are you more frail?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: No.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Come keep my schedule. (LAUGH)  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you spoke with your doctor after the debate. What did he say?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: He said he‚Äì just looked at me and said ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre exhausted.‚Äù That‚Äôs it. I have medical doctors travel with me everywhere. Every President does as you know. Medical doctors some of the best in the world travel with me everywhere I go. I have an ongoing assessment of what I‚Äôm doin‚Äô and they don‚Äôt hesitate to tell me if they think there‚Äôs something wrong.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you said you have an ongoing assessment. Have you had a full neurological and cognitive evaluation?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôve had‚Äì I get a full neurological test everyday with me. And I‚Äôve had a full physical. I had you know I mean I‚Äì I‚Äôve been at Walter Reed for my physicals. I mean‚Äìuhm yes the answer.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äì I know your doctor said he consulted with a neurologist. I‚Äì I guess I‚Äôm asking‚Äì a slightly different question. Have you had the specific cognitive tests and have you had a neurologist a specialist do an examination?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: No. No one said I had to. No one said. They said I‚Äôm good.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Would you be willing to undergo an independent medical evaluation that included neurological and cognit‚Äì cognitive tests and release the results to the American people?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Look. I have a cognitive test every single day. Every day I have that test. Everything I do. You know not only am I campaigning but I‚Äôm running the world. Not‚Äì and that‚Äôs not hi‚Äì sounds like hyperbole but we are the essential nation of the world..  Madeleine Albright was right. And every single day for example today before I came out here I‚Äôm on the phone with‚Äì with the prime minister of‚Äì well anyway I shouldn‚Äôt get into detail but with Netanyahu. I‚Äôm on the phone with the new prime minister of England.  I‚Äôm workin‚Äô on what we were doin‚Äô with regard to‚Äì in Europe with regard to expansion of NATO and whether it‚Äôs gonna stick. I‚Äôm takin‚Äô on Putin. I mean every day there‚Äôs no day I go through there not those decisions I have to make every single day.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And you have been doing that and the American people have been watching yet their concerns about your age and your health are growing. So that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm asking ‚Äì to reassure them would you be willing to have the independent medical evaluation?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Watch me between‚Äì there‚Äôs a lotta time left in this campaign. There‚Äôs over 125 days.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: So the answer‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: They‚Äôll make a decision.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Right‚Äîthe answer right now is no you‚Äì you don‚Äôt want to do that right now.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I‚Äôve already done it.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You talked a lot about your successes in‚Äì at the beginning of this interview. And‚Äì and I don‚Äôt want to dispute that I don‚Äôt want to debate that. But‚Äì as you know elections are about the future not the past. They‚Äôre about tomorrow not yesterday. And the question on so many people‚Äôs minds right now is ‚ÄúCan you serve effectively for the next four years?‚Äù  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: George. I‚Äôm the guy that put NATO together the future. No one thought I could expand it. I‚Äôm the guy that shut Putin down. No one thought could happen. I‚Äôm the guy that put together a South Pacific initiative with AUKUS. I‚Äôm the guy that got 50 nations out‚Äì not only in Europe outside of Europe as well to help Ukraine.  I‚Äôm the guy that got Japanese to expand their budget. I‚Äôm the‚Äì so I mean these‚Äì and for example when I decided we used to have 40% of computer chips. We invented the chip the little chip the computer chip. It‚Äôs in everything from cell phone to weapons.  And so we used to have 40% and we‚Äôre down to virtually nothing. So I get in the plane against the advice of everybody and I fly to South Korea. I convince them to invest in the United States billions of dollars. Now we have tens of billions of dollars being invested in the United States making us back in a position we‚Äôre gonna own that industry again. We have I mean I‚Äì I just‚Äì anyway. I‚Äôm‚Äì I don‚Äôt wanna take too much credit. I have a great staff.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But hold on. My‚Äì I guess my point is all that takes a toll. Do you have the mental and physical capacity to do it for another four years?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I believes so I wouldn‚Äôt be runnin‚Äô if I didn‚Äôt think I did. Look I‚Äôm runnin‚Äô again because I think I understand best what has to be done to take this nation to a completely new new level. We‚Äôre on our way. We‚Äôre on our way. And look. The decision recently made by the Supreme Court on immunity you know the next President of the United States it‚Äôs not just about whether he or she knows what they‚Äôre doin‚Äô.  It‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs not‚Äì not about a con‚Äì a conglomerate of people making decisions. It‚Äôs about the character of the President. The character of the President‚Äôs gonna determine whether or not this Constitution is employed the right way.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let me ask you a tougher more personal question. Are you sure you‚Äôre being honest with yourself when you say you have the mental and physical capacity to serve another four years?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let me ask you a tougher more personal question. Are you sure you‚Äôre being honest with yourself when you say you have the mental and physical capacity to serve another four years?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yes I am because George the last thing I want to do is not be able to meet that. I think as some of senior economist and senior foreign policy specialists say if I stop now I‚Äôd go down in history as a pretty successful President. No one thought I could get done what we got done.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But are you being with honest‚Äì with yourself as well about your ability to defeat Donald Trump right now?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yes. Yes yes yes.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You say that and let me challenge you.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Sure.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Because you were close but behind going into the debate. You‚Äôre further behind now by‚Äì by any measure. It‚Äôs been a two-man race for several months. Inflation has come down. In those last few months he‚Äôs become a convicted felon. Yet you‚Äôre still falling further behind.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: You guys keep saying that. George do you‚Äì look you know polling better than anybody. Do you think polling data as accurate as it used to be?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I don‚Äôt think so but I think when you look at all the polling data right now it shows that he‚Äôs certainly ahead in the popular vote probably even more ahead in the battleground states. And one of the other key factors there is it shows that in many of the battleground states the Democrats who are running for Senate and the House are doing better than you are.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: That‚Äôs not unusual in some states. I carried an awful lotta Democrats last time I ran in 2020. Look I remember them tellin‚Äô me the same thing in 2020. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt win. The polls show I can‚Äôt win.‚Äù Remember 2024‚Äì 2020 the red wave was coming.  Before the vote I said ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not gonna happen. We‚Äôre gonna win.‚Äù We did better in an off-year than almost any incumbent President ever has done. They said in 2023 (STATIC) all the tough (UNINTEL) we‚Äôre not gonna win. I went into all those areas and all those‚Äì all those districts and we won.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: All that is true but 2020 was a close race. And your approval rating has dropped significantly since then. I think the last poll I saw was at about 36%.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Woah woah woah  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: The number of Americans who think you‚Äôre too old to serve has doubled since 2020. Wouldn‚Äôt a clear-eyed political calculus tell you that it‚Äôs gonna be much tougher to win in 2024?.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Not when you‚Äôre running against a pathological liar. Not when he hadn‚Äôt been challenged in a way that he‚Äôs about to be challenged. Not when people‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You‚Äôve had months to challenge him.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh sure I had months but I was also doin‚Äô a hell of a lot of other things like wars around the world like keeping NATO together like working‚Äì anyway. But look.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Do you really believe you‚Äôre not behind right now?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I think it‚Äôs in‚Äì all the pollsters I talk to tell me it‚Äôs a tossup. It‚Äôs a tossup. And when I‚Äôm behind there‚Äôs only one poll I‚Äôm really far behind CBS Poll and NBC I mean excuse me. And‚Äì uh‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: New York‚Äì New York Times and NBC both have‚Äì have you about six points behind in the popular vote.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: That‚Äôs exactly right. New York Times had me behind before anything having to do with this race‚Äì had me hind‚Äì behind ten points. Ten points they had me behind. Nothing‚Äôs changed substantially since the debate in the New York Times poll.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Just when you look at the reality though Mr. President I mean you won the popular vote‚Äì in‚Äì in 2020 but it was still deadly close in the electoral college‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: By 7 million votes.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Yes. But you‚Äôre behind now in the popular vote.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt‚Äì I don‚Äôt buy that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Is it worth the risk?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt think anybody‚Äôs more qualified to be President or win this race than me.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know the heart of your case against Donald Trump is that he‚Äôs only out for himself putting his personal interests ahead of the national interest. How do you respond to critics who say that by staying in the race you‚Äôre doing the same thing?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh come on. Well I don‚Äôt think those critics know what they‚Äôre talkin‚Äô about.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: They‚Äôre just wrong?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: They‚Äôre just wrong. Look Trump is a pathological liar. Trump is‚Äì he is‚Äì you ever seen anything Trump did that benefited sa‚Äì somebody else and not him? You can‚Äôt answer I know.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äôve‚Äì I‚Äôve questioned him and his allies as persistently as any journalist has.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh I know you have. I‚Äôm not being critical. I‚Äôm not being critical but look I mean the man is a congenital liar. As I said they pointed out in that debate he lied 27‚Äì 28 times‚Äì times whatever number over 20 times. Talk about how good his economy was how he brought down inflation how‚Äì this is a guy who unlike‚Äì only other President oth‚Äì other than him is Hoover who lost more jobs than he created.  This is a guy who told us to put bleach in our arms to deal with COVID with a million‚Äì over a million people died. This is a guy who talks about wantin‚Äô to get rid of the healthcare provision we put in place. This is a guy who wants to give the power back to big pharma to be able to charge exorbitant prices for drugs. This is a guy who wants to undo every single thing I‚Äôve done every single‚Äì every single thing.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I understand that. I understand that‚Äôs why you want to stay in the race but have you convinced yourself that only you can defeat him?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I convinced myself of two things. I‚Äôm the most qualified person to beat him and I know how to get things done.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: If you can be convinced that you cannot defeat Donald Trump will you stand down?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: (LAUGH)- It depends on‚Äì on if the Lord Almighty comes down and tells me that I might do that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Well if‚Äì I mean on a more practical level The Washington Post just reported in the last hour that Senator Mark Warner is‚Äì is assembling a group of Senators together to try and convince you to stand down because they don‚Äôt think you can win.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well Mark is a good man. We‚Äôve never had (UNINTEL). He also tried to get the nomination too. Mark‚Äôs not‚Äì Mark and I have a different perspective. I respect him.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And if Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries and Nancy Pelosi come down and say ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre worried that if you stay in the race we‚Äôre gonna lose the House and the Senate‚Äù how will you respond?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äì I‚Äôd go into detail with them. I‚Äôve speaken (PH) to all of them in detail including Jim Clyburn every one of 'em. They all said I should stay in the race‚Äì stay in the race. No one said‚Äì none of the people said I should leave.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But if they do?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well it‚Äôs like (LAUGH) they‚Äôre not gonna do that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You‚Äôre sure?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well Yeah I‚Äôm sure. Look. I mean if the Lord Almighty came down and said ‚ÄúJoe get outta the race‚Äù I‚Äôd get outta the race. The Lord Almighty‚Äôs not comin‚Äô down. I mean these hypotheticals George if I mean it‚Äôs all‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But‚Äì but it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs not that hypothetical anymore. I‚Äì I‚Äì I‚Äì I grant that the‚Äì they have not k‚Äì requested a meeting but it‚Äôs been reported‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: But they‚Äì I met with them. I met with a lotta these people. I talk with them regularly. I had an hour conversation with Hakeem. I had more time (UNITEL)with Jim Clyburn. I spent time with many hours off and on in the last little bit with Chuck Schumer. It‚Äôs not like‚Äì I had all the governors‚Äì all the governors.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I agree that the Lord Almighty‚Äôs not gonna come down but if‚Äì if‚Äì if you are told reliably from your allies from your friends and supporters in the Democratic Party in the House and the Senate that they‚Äôre concerned you‚Äôre gonna lose the House and the Senate if you stay in what will you do?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôm not gonna answer that question. It‚Äôs not gonna happen.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: What‚Äôs your plan to turn the campaign around?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: You saw it today. How many‚Äì how many people draw crowds like I did today? Find me more enthusiastic than today? Huh?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I mean have‚Äì I don‚Äôt think you wanna play the crowd game. Donald Trump can draw big crowds. There‚Äôs no question about that.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: He can draw a big crowd but what does he say? Who‚Äì who does he have? I‚Äôm the guy supposedly in trouble. We raised $38 million within four days after this. Over‚Äì we have over a million individual contributors individual contributors. That‚Äì that‚Äôs less than 200 bucks. We have‚Äì I mean I‚Äôm not seen what you‚Äôre‚Äì you‚Äôre proposing.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You haven‚Äôt seen the‚Äì the fall-off in the polls? You haven‚Äôt seen the reports of discontent in the Democratic Party House Democrats Senate Democrats?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôve seen it from the press.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know I‚Äôve heard from dozens of your supporters over the last few days and a variety of views I grant you that. But the prevailing sentiment is this. They love you and they will be forever grateful to you for defeating Donald Trump in 2020.  They think you‚Äôve done a great job as President a lot of the successes you outlined. But they are worried about you and the country. And they don‚Äôt think you can win. They want you to go with grace and they will cheer you if you do. What do you say to that?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I say the vast majority are not where that‚Äì those folks are. I don‚Äôt doubt there are some folks there. Have you ever seen a group‚Äì ta‚Äì time when elected officials running for office aren‚Äôt little worried? Have you ever seen that? I‚Äôve not. Same thing happened in 2020. ‚ÄúOh Biden I don‚Äôt know. Man what‚Äôs he gonna do? He may bring me down he may (PH).‚Äù  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Mr. President I‚Äôve never seen a President 36% approval get reelected.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I don‚Äôt believe that‚Äôs my approval rating. That‚Äôs not what our polls show.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And if you stay in and Trump is elected and everything you‚Äôre warning about comes to pass how will you feel in January?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôll feel as long as I gave it my all and I did the good as job as I know I can do that‚Äôs what this is about. Look George. Think of it this way. You‚Äôve heard me say this before. I think the United States and the world is at an inflection point when the things that happen in the next several years are gonna determine what the next six seven decades are gonna be like.  And who‚Äôs gonna be able to hold NATO together like me? Who‚Äôs gonna be able to be in a position where I‚Äôm able to keep the Pacific Basin in a position where we‚Äôre‚Äì we‚Äôre at least checkmating China now? Who‚Äôs gonna‚Äì who‚Äôs gonna do that? Who has that reach? Who has‚Äì who knows all these pe‚Ä¶? We‚Äôre gonna have I guess a good way to judge me is you‚Äôre gonna have now the NATO conference here in the United States next week. Come listen. See what they say.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Mr. President thanks for your time.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Thank you. Appreciate it. post_body: Stop Project 2025 In case you guys didn‚Äôt know Project 2025 is bad news for pretty much all of us US citizens. I‚Äôd suggest looking up and reading over Project 2025 because after reading it Joe Biden being ‚Äútoo old‚Äù to be in charge will be the last thing you‚Äôll want to worry about. Heck I can only hope you will realize after reading it that it‚Äôs the very reason why this election is too important to sit out. Literally everyone‚Äôs rights are on the line; women‚Äôs rights the LGBTQIA community‚Äôs rights the elderly federal workers the military and even people of every ethnicity.   As a matter of fact I‚Äôll save you the trouble of searching for Project 2025 and provide you with the PDF of it right here: https://static.project2025.org/2025_MandateForLeadership_FULL.pdf
I hope Trump and Biden both die before Election Day and their parties aren‚Äôt able to find replacements in Time forcing them to drop out of the raceÔøº.

post_body: Markled ‚ÄúBidened‚Äù   Philly radio host fired by WURD Radio after using 4 of the 8 questions given to her by the Biden campaign. ‚ÄúShe didnt get fired for using the questions she was fired for TELLING everyone she used them. ‚Äù

Biden Insists to Democrats He Is Fine to Keep Running For President and Continue Driving at Night President Biden made clear he would not step aside from the presidential race delivering a fiery message on ‚ÄúMorning Joe‚Äù and in a letter to Congressional Democrats a day after some House members privately said he should drop out. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. Everyone wants me to stop running for president and stop driving at night. I might be 81 but I can still do both!‚Äù Biden insisted despite more and more calls for him to stop doing both things. ‚ÄúIf any of these guys don‚Äôt think I should run run against me. And I‚Äôm still a great driver. That garbage can came out of nowhere the other day.‚Äú
We all need to be aware that the media is flat out inventing stories about democrats trying to get Biden to step down.

Full transcript of the ABC News exclusive interview with President Joe Biden.  120 DAYS TO ELECTION DAY  ABC‚Äôs George Stephanopoulos‚Äô exclusive interview with President Biden  July 5 2024 9:10 PM  One-on-one with President Biden: ABC News Exclusive  ABC‚Äôs George Stephanopoulos  President Joe Biden in his first television interview since his CNN debate with former President Donald Trump sat down with ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos in Madison Wisconsin on Friday.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Mr. President thank you for doing this.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Thank you for having me.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let‚Äôs start with the debate. eh You and your team said have said you had a bad night. But your‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Sure did.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But your friend Nancy Pelosi actually framed the question that I think is on the minds of millions of Americans. Was this a bad episode or the sign of a more serious condition?  <!-- more --> PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: It was a bad episode. No indication of any serious condition. I was exhausted. I didn‚Äôt listen to my instincts in terms of preparing and‚Äì and a bad night.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know you say you were exhausted. And‚Äì and I know you‚Äôve said that before as well but you came‚Äì and you did have a tough month. But you came home from Europe about 11 or 12 days before the debate spent six days in Camp David. Why wasn‚Äôt that enough rest time enough recovery time?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Because I was sick. I was feeling terrible. Matter of fact the docs with me. I asked if they did a COVID test because they‚Äôre trying to figure out what was wrong. They did a test to see whether or not I had some infection you know a virus. I didn‚Äôt. I just had a really bad cold.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And‚Äì did you ever watch the debate afterwards?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt think I did no.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Well what I‚Äôm try‚Äì what I want to get at is what were you experiencing as you were going through the debate? Did you know how badly it was going?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yeah look. The whole way I prepared nobody‚Äôs fault mine. Nobody‚Äôs fault but mine. I uh‚Äì I prepared what I usually would do sittin‚Äô down as I did come back with foreign leaders or National Security Council for explicit detail. And I realized‚Äìbout partway through that you know all‚Äì I get quoted the New York Times had me down at ten points before the debate nine now or whatever the hell it is. The fact of the matter is what I looked at is that he also lied 28 times. I couldn‚Äôt‚Äì I mean the way the debate ran not‚Äì my fault no one else‚Äôs fault no one else‚Äôs fault.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But it seemed like you were having trouble from the first question in even before he spoke.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I just had a bad night. You‚Äôve had some bad interviews once in a while. I‚Äì I can‚Äôt remember any but I‚Äôm sure you did.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äôve had plenty. I guess the question of‚Äì the problem is here for a lot of Americans watching is you‚Äôve said going back to 2020 ‚ÄúWatch me‚Äù to people who are concerned about your age. And you know 50 million Americans watched that debate. It seemed to confirm fears they already had.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well look. After that debate I did ten major events in a row including until 2:00 in the morning after the debate. I did events in North Carolina. I did events in‚Äîin in Georgia did events like this today large crowds overwhelming response no‚Äì no‚Äì no slipping. And so I just had a bad night. I don‚Äôt know why.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And‚Äì how‚Äì how quickly did it‚Äì did it come to you that you were having that bad night?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well it came to me I was havin‚Äô a bad night when I realized that even when I was answering a question even though they turned his mic off he was still shouting. And I‚Äì I let it distract me. I‚Äì I‚Äôm not blaming it on that but I realized that I just wasn‚Äôt in control.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Part of the other concern is that‚Äì this seems to fit into a pattern of decline that has been reported on recently. New York Times had a headline on July 2nd ‚ÄúBiden‚Äôs lapses are said to be increasingly common and worrisome.‚Äù Here‚Äôs what they wrote.  ‚ÄúPeople who‚Äôve spent time with President Biden over the last few months or so said the lapses appear to have grown more frequent more pronounced and after Thursday d‚Äì Thursday‚Äôs debate more worrisome. By many accounts as evidenced by video footage observation and interviews Mr. Biden is not the same today as he was even when he took office three-and-a-half years ago.‚Äù Similar reporting in The Washington Post and the Wall Street Journal. Are you the same man today that you were when you took office three-and-a-half years ago?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: In terms of successes yes. I also was the guy who put together a peace plan for the Middle East that may be comin‚Äô to fruition. I was also the guy that expanded NATO. I was also the guy that grew the economy. All the individual things that were done were ideas I had or I fulfilled. I moved on.  And so for example you know ‚ÄúWe-Well that was true then what‚Äôs Biden done lately?‚Äù Di-you-just just see today just announced 200000 new jobs. We‚Äôre movin‚Äô in the direction that no one‚Äôs ever taken on. I know you know this from days in‚Äì in‚Äì in the‚Äì in the government.  I took on big pharma. I beat them. No one said I could beat them. I took on all the things we said we got done were told we couldn‚Äôt get done. And part of it is what I said when I ran was I wanted to do three things: Restore some decency to the office restore some support for the middle class instead of trickle down economics both from the middle out and the bottom up the way the wealthy still do fine everyone does better and unite the country.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But what has all that work over the last three-and-a-half years cost you physically mentally emotionally?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I‚Äì I‚Äì I just think it cost me a really bad night bad run but you know I‚Äì George. I have‚Äì I‚Äôm optimistic about this country. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre a country of losers that he points out. I don‚Äôt think America‚Äôs in tough shape. I think America is on the cusp of breaking through in so many incredible opportunities.  In this next term I‚Äôm gonna make sure we gotta‚Äì straighten out the tax system. I‚Äôm gonna make sure we‚Äôre in a situation where we have healthcare for all people where we‚Äôre in a position where we have‚Äì have childcare and eldercare free up‚Äì and all these things.  One thing I‚Äôm proudest of is remember when my economic plan was put forward? A lot of the mainstream economists said ‚ÄúThis is not gonna work.‚Äù Guess what? We now have 16 Nobel laureates 16 of ‚Äòem in economics saying that ‚ÄúBiden‚Äôs next term would be a sig‚Äì enor‚Äì based on what he wants to do enormous success.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs plan would cause a recession and sig-nif‚Äì gi‚Äì increase inflation. I‚Äôve made great progress and that‚Äôs what I plan on doin‚Äô. And we can do this.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äì I‚Äì I understand that and I‚Äôm not disputing that. What I‚Äôm asking you is‚Äì about your personal situation. Do you dispute that there have been more lapses especially in the last several months?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Can I run the 100 in 10 flat? No. But I‚Äôm still in good shape.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Are you more frail?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: No.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Come keep my schedule. (LAUGH)  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you spoke with your doctor after the debate. What did he say?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: He said he‚Äì just looked at me and said ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre exhausted.‚Äù That‚Äôs it. I have medical doctors travel with me everywhere. Every President does as you know. Medical doctors some of the best in the world travel with me everywhere I go. I have an ongoing assessment of what I‚Äôm doin‚Äô and they don‚Äôt hesitate to tell me if they think there‚Äôs something wrong.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I know you said you have an ongoing assessment. Have you had a full neurological and cognitive evaluation?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôve had‚Äì I get a full neurological test everyday with me. And I‚Äôve had a full physical. I had you know I mean I‚Äì I‚Äôve been at Walter Reed for my physicals. I mean‚Äìuhm yes the answer.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äì I know your doctor said he consulted with a neurologist. I‚Äì I guess I‚Äôm asking‚Äì a slightly different question. Have you had the specific cognitive tests and have you had a neurologist a specialist do an examination?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: No. No one said I had to. No one said. They said I‚Äôm good.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Would you be willing to undergo an independent medical evaluation that included neurological and cognit‚Äì cognitive tests and release the results to the American people?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Look. I have a cognitive test every single day. Every day I have that test. Everything I do. You know not only am I campaigning but I‚Äôm running the world. Not‚Äì and that‚Äôs not hi‚Äì sounds like hyperbole but we are the essential nation of the world..  Madeleine Albright was right. And every single day for example today before I came out here I‚Äôm on the phone with‚Äì with the prime minister of‚Äì well anyway I shouldn‚Äôt get into detail but with Netanyahu. I‚Äôm on the phone with the new prime minister of England.  I‚Äôm workin‚Äô on what we were doin‚Äô with regard to‚Äì in Europe with regard to expansion of NATO and whether it‚Äôs gonna stick. I‚Äôm takin‚Äô on Putin. I mean every day there‚Äôs no day I go through there not those decisions I have to make every single day.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And you have been doing that and the American people have been watching yet their concerns about your age and your health are growing. So that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm asking ‚Äì to reassure them would you be willing to have the independent medical evaluation?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Watch me between‚Äì there‚Äôs a lotta time left in this campaign. There‚Äôs over 125 days.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: So the answer‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: They‚Äôll make a decision.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Right‚Äîthe answer right now is no you‚Äì you don‚Äôt want to do that right now.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I‚Äôve already done it.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You talked a lot about your successes in‚Äì at the beginning of this interview. And‚Äì and I don‚Äôt want to dispute that I don‚Äôt want to debate that. But‚Äì as you know elections are about the future not the past. They‚Äôre about tomorrow not yesterday. And the question on so many people‚Äôs minds right now is ‚ÄúCan you serve effectively for the next four years?‚Äù  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: George. I‚Äôm the guy that put NATO together the future. No one thought I could expand it. I‚Äôm the guy that shut Putin down. No one thought could happen. I‚Äôm the guy that put together a South Pacific initiative with AUKUS. I‚Äôm the guy that got 50 nations out‚Äì not only in Europe outside of Europe as well to help Ukraine.  I‚Äôm the guy that got Japanese to expand their budget. I‚Äôm the‚Äì so I mean these‚Äì and for example when I decided we used to have 40% of computer chips. We invented the chip the little chip the computer chip. It‚Äôs in everything from cell phone to weapons.  And so we used to have 40% and we‚Äôre down to virtually nothing. So I get in the plane against the advice of everybody and I fly to South Korea. I convince them to invest in the United States billions of dollars. Now we have tens of billions of dollars being invested in the United States making us back in a position we‚Äôre gonna own that industry again. We have I mean I‚Äì I just‚Äì anyway. I‚Äôm‚Äì I don‚Äôt wanna take too much credit. I have a great staff.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But hold on. My‚Äì I guess my point is all that takes a toll. Do you have the mental and physical capacity to do it for another four years?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I believes so I wouldn‚Äôt be runnin‚Äô if I didn‚Äôt think I did. Look I‚Äôm runnin‚Äô again because I think I understand best what has to be done to take this nation to a completely new new level. We‚Äôre on our way. We‚Äôre on our way. And look. The decision recently made by the Supreme Court on immunity you know the next President of the United States it‚Äôs not just about whether he or she knows what they‚Äôre doin‚Äô.  It‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs not‚Äì not about a con‚Äì a conglomerate of people making decisions. It‚Äôs about the character of the President. The character of the President‚Äôs gonna determine whether or not this Constitution is employed the right way.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let me ask you a tougher more personal question. Are you sure you‚Äôre being honest with yourself when you say you have the mental and physical capacity to serve another four years?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Let me ask you a tougher more personal question. Are you sure you‚Äôre being honest with yourself when you say you have the mental and physical capacity to serve another four years?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yes I am because George the last thing I want to do is not be able to meet that. I think as some of senior economist and senior foreign policy specialists say if I stop now I‚Äôd go down in history as a pretty successful President. No one thought I could get done what we got done.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But are you being with honest‚Äì with yourself as well about your ability to defeat Donald Trump right now?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Yes. Yes yes yes.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You say that and let me challenge you.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Sure.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Because you were close but behind going into the debate. You‚Äôre further behind now by‚Äì by any measure. It‚Äôs been a two-man race for several months. Inflation has come down. In those last few months he‚Äôs become a convicted felon. Yet you‚Äôre still falling further behind.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: You guys keep saying that. George do you‚Äì look you know polling better than anybody. Do you think polling data as accurate as it used to be?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I don‚Äôt think so but I think when you look at all the polling data right now it shows that he‚Äôs certainly ahead in the popular vote probably even more ahead in the battleground states. And one of the other key factors there is it shows that in many of the battleground states the Democrats who are running for Senate and the House are doing better than you are.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: That‚Äôs not unusual in some states. I carried an awful lotta Democrats last time I ran in 2020. Look I remember them tellin‚Äô me the same thing in 2020. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt win. The polls show I can‚Äôt win.‚Äù Remember 2024‚Äì 2020 the red wave was coming.  Before the vote I said ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not gonna happen. We‚Äôre gonna win.‚Äù We did better in an off-year than almost any incumbent President ever has done. They said in 2023 (STATIC) all the tough (UNINTEL) we‚Äôre not gonna win. I went into all those areas and all those‚Äì all those districts and we won.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: All that is true but 2020 was a close race. And your approval rating has dropped significantly since then. I think the last poll I saw was at about 36%.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Woah woah woah  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: The number of Americans who think you‚Äôre too old to serve has doubled since 2020. Wouldn‚Äôt a clear-eyed political calculus tell you that it‚Äôs gonna be much tougher to win in 2024?.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Not when you‚Äôre running against a pathological liar. Not when he hadn‚Äôt been challenged in a way that he‚Äôs about to be challenged. Not when people‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You‚Äôve had months to challenge him.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh sure I had months but I was also doin‚Äô a hell of a lot of other things like wars around the world like keeping NATO together like working‚Äì anyway. But look.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Do you really believe you‚Äôre not behind right now?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I think it‚Äôs in‚Äì all the pollsters I talk to tell me it‚Äôs a tossup. It‚Äôs a tossup. And when I‚Äôm behind there‚Äôs only one poll I‚Äôm really far behind CBS Poll and NBC I mean excuse me. And‚Äì uh‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: New York‚Äì New York Times and NBC both have‚Äì have you about six points behind in the popular vote.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: That‚Äôs exactly right. New York Times had me behind before anything having to do with this race‚Äì had me hind‚Äì behind ten points. Ten points they had me behind. Nothing‚Äôs changed substantially since the debate in the New York Times poll.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Just when you look at the reality though Mr. President I mean you won the popular vote‚Äì in‚Äì in 2020 but it was still deadly close in the electoral college‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: By 7 million votes.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Yes. But you‚Äôre behind now in the popular vote.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt‚Äì I don‚Äôt buy that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Is it worth the risk?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I don‚Äôt think anybody‚Äôs more qualified to be President or win this race than me.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know the heart of your case against Donald Trump is that he‚Äôs only out for himself putting his personal interests ahead of the national interest. How do you respond to critics who say that by staying in the race you‚Äôre doing the same thing?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh come on. Well I don‚Äôt think those critics know what they‚Äôre talkin‚Äô about.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: They‚Äôre just wrong?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: They‚Äôre just wrong. Look Trump is a pathological liar. Trump is‚Äì he is‚Äì you ever seen anything Trump did that benefited sa‚Äì somebody else and not him? You can‚Äôt answer I know.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I‚Äôve‚Äì I‚Äôve questioned him and his allies as persistently as any journalist has.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Oh I know you have. I‚Äôm not being critical. I‚Äôm not being critical but look I mean the man is a congenital liar. As I said they pointed out in that debate he lied 27‚Äì 28 times‚Äì times whatever number over 20 times. Talk about how good his economy was how he brought down inflation how‚Äì this is a guy who unlike‚Äì only other President oth‚Äì other than him is Hoover who lost more jobs than he created.  This is a guy who told us to put bleach in our arms to deal with COVID with a million‚Äì over a million people died. This is a guy who talks about wantin‚Äô to get rid of the healthcare provision we put in place. This is a guy who wants to give the power back to big pharma to be able to charge exorbitant prices for drugs. This is a guy who wants to undo every single thing I‚Äôve done every single‚Äì every single thing.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I understand that. I understand that‚Äôs why you want to stay in the race but have you convinced yourself that only you can defeat him?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I convinced myself of two things. I‚Äôm the most qualified person to beat him and I know how to get things done.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: If you can be convinced that you cannot defeat Donald Trump will you stand down?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: (LAUGH)- It depends on‚Äì on if the Lord Almighty comes down and tells me that I might do that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Well if‚Äì I mean on a more practical level The Washington Post just reported in the last hour that Senator Mark Warner is‚Äì is assembling a group of Senators together to try and convince you to stand down because they don‚Äôt think you can win.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well Mark is a good man. We‚Äôve never had (UNINTEL). He also tried to get the nomination too. Mark‚Äôs not‚Äì Mark and I have a different perspective. I respect him.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And if Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries and Nancy Pelosi come down and say ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre worried that if you stay in the race we‚Äôre gonna lose the House and the Senate‚Äù how will you respond?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äì I‚Äôd go into detail with them. I‚Äôve speaken (PH) to all of them in detail including Jim Clyburn every one of 'em. They all said I should stay in the race‚Äì stay in the race. No one said‚Äì none of the people said I should leave.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But if they do?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well it‚Äôs like (LAUGH) they‚Äôre not gonna do that.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You‚Äôre sure?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well Yeah I‚Äôm sure. Look. I mean if the Lord Almighty came down and said ‚ÄúJoe get outta the race‚Äù I‚Äôd get outta the race. The Lord Almighty‚Äôs not comin‚Äô down. I mean these hypotheticals George if I mean it‚Äôs all‚Äì  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: But‚Äì but it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs‚Äì it‚Äôs not that hypothetical anymore. I‚Äì I‚Äì I‚Äì I grant that the‚Äì they have not k‚Äì requested a meeting but it‚Äôs been reported‚Äì  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: But they‚Äì I met with them. I met with a lotta these people. I talk with them regularly. I had an hour conversation with Hakeem. I had more time (UNITEL)with Jim Clyburn. I spent time with many hours off and on in the last little bit with Chuck Schumer. It‚Äôs not like‚Äì I had all the governors‚Äì all the governors.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I agree that the Lord Almighty‚Äôs not gonna come down but if‚Äì if‚Äì if you are told reliably from your allies from your friends and supporters in the Democratic Party in the House and the Senate that they‚Äôre concerned you‚Äôre gonna lose the House and the Senate if you stay in what will you do?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôm not gonna answer that question. It‚Äôs not gonna happen.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: What‚Äôs your plan to turn the campaign around?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: You saw it today. How many‚Äì how many people draw crowds like I did today? Find me more enthusiastic than today? Huh?  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: I mean have‚Äì I don‚Äôt think you wanna play the crowd game. Donald Trump can draw big crowds. There‚Äôs no question about that.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: He can draw a big crowd but what does he say? Who‚Äì who does he have? I‚Äôm the guy supposedly in trouble. We raised $38 million within four days after this. Over‚Äì we have over a million individual contributors individual contributors. That‚Äì that‚Äôs less than 200 bucks. We have‚Äì I mean I‚Äôm not seen what you‚Äôre‚Äì you‚Äôre proposing.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You haven‚Äôt seen the‚Äì the fall-off in the polls? You haven‚Äôt seen the reports of discontent in the Democratic Party House Democrats Senate Democrats?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôve seen it from the press.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: You know I‚Äôve heard from dozens of your supporters over the last few days and a variety of views I grant you that. But the prevailing sentiment is this. They love you and they will be forever grateful to you for defeating Donald Trump in 2020.  They think you‚Äôve done a great job as President a lot of the successes you outlined. But they are worried about you and the country. And they don‚Äôt think you can win. They want you to go with grace and they will cheer you if you do. What do you say to that?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I say the vast majority are not where that‚Äì those folks are. I don‚Äôt doubt there are some folks there. Have you ever seen a group‚Äì ta‚Äì time when elected officials running for office aren‚Äôt little worried? Have you ever seen that? I‚Äôve not. Same thing happened in 2020. ‚ÄúOh Biden I don‚Äôt know. Man what‚Äôs he gonna do? He may bring me down he may (PH).‚Äù  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: Mr. President I‚Äôve never seen a President 36% approval get reelected.  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: Well I don‚Äôt believe that‚Äôs my approval rating. That‚Äôs not what our polls show.  GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS: And if you stay in and Trump is elected and everything you‚Äôre warning about comes to pass how will you feel in January?  PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: I‚Äôll feel as long as I gave it my all and I did the good as job as I know I can do that‚Äôs what this is about. Look George. Think of it this way. You‚Äôve heard me say this before. I think the United States and the world is at an inflection point when the things that happen in the next several years are gonna determine what the next six seven decades are gonna be like.  And who‚Äôs gonna be able to hold NATO together like me? Who‚Äôs gonna be able to be in a position where I‚Äôm able to keep the Pacific Basin in a position where we‚Äôre‚Äì we‚Äôre at least checkmating China now? Who‚Äôs gonna‚Äì who‚Äôs gonna do that? Who has that reach? Who has‚Äì who knows all these pe‚Ä¶? We‚Äôre gonna have I guess a good way to judge me is you‚Äôre gonna have now the NATO conference here in the United States next week. Honestly I do think we need to see how normalized Trump‚Äôs behavior has been to our country.  Biden had one bad debate performance and every single day since there have been waves of articles asking if Biden should step down.  Trump keeps getting basic facts mixed up (like the fact he‚Äôs running against Biden not Obama) lies constantly tried to overthrow the 2020 election had govt docs in Mar-A-Largo‚Äôs bathroom and Project 2025 has horrific consequences for the country.  And yet‚Ä¶nothing. I‚Äôve seen more articles wondering if Biden should step down due to a bad debate than articles about Project 2025.   The unspoken idea is that Biden is the adult in the room Trump can‚Äôt be reasoned with so if anything can be done to prevent a lot of people‚Äôs rights being taken away it‚Äôs on Biden and the Dems.   Which then gives people the impression that Biden and Trump are candidates on equal ground. Which they aren‚Äôt. The bar is on the floor for Trump.   Look how much pushback Biden got for a bad debate performance. We‚Äôre getting swamped with articles about how he should step down. Look how much pushback Trump is getting for any of the actions I listed above. No articles are coming out for him to step down bc everyone‚Äôs decided he can‚Äôt be reasoned with.  Honestly just please remember this if you‚Äôre thinking about not voting this Nov. The candidates are not equal elections have consequences and assuming that we‚Äôll have the same outcome if Biden gets elected or if Trump gets elected is due to a massive gaslighting campaign on the American people.

No Debate About Joe Biden‚Äôs Lucidity Joe Biden is unfit to be president. Wait: I just saw the debate. That‚Äôs even worse. It‚Äôs a good thing the position is part-time or we‚Äôd be doomed. The temp job he staffs doesn‚Äôt require him to be prepared or energetic so there‚Äôs no need to fret about news breaking while waiting for dinner.  Someone in his ninth decade who‚Äôs always been a numbskull insists he can keep a job where work responsibilities can occur in any time zone. The technical commander-in-chief might need to deal with Kim Jong Un taking the parking brake off their nukes during North Korean business hours which might interrupt Joe Bide Un‚Äôs Woody Woodpecker time. The choice between a half-declined inveterate liar or a fully-declined one will make November even more fun than now.  What time is the meeting to establish if dropping out should be official? That‚Äôll determine whether they have to deal with Doctor Jekyll or Mister Bide. Dissolving the special energy vitamin in his chocolate milk is just another thankless task for the administration‚Äôs flunkies. You never praised them for making gasoline slightly cheaper than the mysteriously astronomical rate last summer under whoever headed the state then.  Biden‚Äôs cogency is like an eclipse: you appreciate it more because it‚Äôs rare. The only factor mitigating slumping is that he was sliding at the start. Anyone who endured him speaking at any time while he was vice president or senator knows cognitive deterioration began far before his oatmeal brain started leaking.  Friends and family must care about Grampy Joey if they want him to keep working. But cynics suspect close grifters may be motivated by more than having their beloved relative continue to feel purpose. Democrats think everyone else is a conniving schemer too.  Doctor Jill Biden violates the Hippocratic Oath with stubborn elder abuse. It‚Äôs tough to focus on medical ethics as a mob wife. The crime family needs their meal ticket to keep the title even if he isn‚Äôt technically doing anything presidential. For Democrats the claim is all it takes. Biden leads like Obamacare gave everyone awesome affordable insurance.  Life is worth whatever those in the compassionate faction conclude. From aborting the inconvenient to propping up a president who should be talking to a potted plant in a nursing home Democrats are consistent about how much they value others.  This White House‚Äôs sole skill is proving conspiracies true. If you‚Äôre a Democrat ticked that Biden stubbornly won‚Äôt retire despite his inability to perform complicated tasks like identifying himself without pointing to his name tag make sure you weren‚Äôt shrieking at Republicans a few weeks ago for noticing Biden needed to be led off the stage by his last manager.  Very fair journalists hope you forget like you‚Äôre the present president. Guardians of truth went from claiming Barack Obama guiding off Biden was a truther conspiracy to orchestrating scrambling for a replacement nominee faster than they went from claiming shutting down hairdressers for the sake of halting the virus was mandated for your own good to a voluntary wise suggestion.  Everything this addled president remembers he believes is based in pretending reality isn‚Äôt happening. The same media that lied about Hunter‚Äôs laptop the diverse mosaic that open borders would create how taking rights would keep you from getting sick and corporations discovering greed in 2021 claims Joe Biden‚Äôs rough debate was a one-off. I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôre honest this once.  The time to have a talk with Biden about not being president was in 1972. His cold‚Äôs primary symptom is getting everything wrong. He‚Äôs had it for over half a century. The incumbent came up with the notion of getting rich by printing more money before he forgot his career.  The 25th Amendment is just another they loathe. You may as well want to own an AR-15 while announcing why the government can‚Äôt prevent such. The genie‚Äôs wish always turns into a curse. As with inflation ruining the aforementioned cash handout scheme Biden‚Äôs party never learns to abandon quick fixes.  Pushy federal goons wanted a defiant president who refused to be constrained by niceties like waiting for Congress to pass a bill. Now the executive ordering specialist applies the same stubbornness to remaining sitting in his fancy swivel chair. Frankenstein whines about his monster.  Foes of vexing checks and balances have always wanted a king. Now he doesn‚Äôt have power and they still kvetch. A clandestine committee voting on one person‚Äôs alleged decisions is the closest Democrats get to democratic.  Wrestling fans enjoy pretend bouts despite knowing results are phony. Dispensing with the charade might work for a kayfabe presidency. Whoever‚Äôs really steering in the Oval Office while Biden sorts his Happy Meal toys might not be as effective as raising inflation despite best worst efforts. America‚Äôs best hope until 2029 is a country-ruining president who can‚Äôt complete his checklist anymore including writing it.  The figurative megalomaniacal understudy who performed the role for the election would act just as terribly. It‚Äôs ideas that matter which disappoints personality cults. The staff is already merely projecting goals based on estimating what the ostensible supervisor would want. The AI presidency is advanced considering the figurehead was born before color television.  The one-person branch is already being run by committee. Breaking yet another office rule is simultaneously dejecting and reassuring. Daft policies that could be churned out by algorithm show that idiocy is predictable even if the idiots change. Subtracting Biden‚Äôs regrettable personality would be the most pleasant part of his second try.  Why depose someone who can Velcro his own sneakers around midday? This term or the next wouldn‚Äôt change much upon conceding that the guy in charge isn‚Äôt. His mental meltdown offers the best chance to limit the damage he inflicts. The nation really lucked out.  Anyone honest is used to him being out of it. If it makes Democrats feel better Joe Biden was a nastily moronic failure when he could form words. He‚Äôs the lucky one: he doesn‚Äôt know he‚Äôs boss.
